subject: mock-sensor-tool: Add first iteration
commitMessage:
mock-sensor-tool: Add first iteration

The Mock Sensor Tool provides an easy way for users to overload sensor
data at a kernel interface level through the use of ptrace. The design
document can be found here:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/37869

Tested: integration testing was done for a wide variety of inputs on a
romulus instance running phosphor-hwmon. Currently building a testing
doc to document specifics and working on unit testing next with gTest.

Change-Id: Icbe1f85f82370d55dd62f4783b3332eb2a57f6cd
Signed-off-by: Jun Ho Park <junhopark2001@gmail.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.
Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 3:

Please ensure you add a .clang-format for this directory and run it (it'll tidy up the trailing whitespaces you have in your code)

You should copy the .clang-format from https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/style/cpp/.clang-format

Because you're building from meson.build, you should also create a .gitignore file that has these 2 lines:

```
/build*/
/subprojects/*/
```

Patch Set 3:

Hello,

This it the mock sensor tool implementation from the design doc here: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/37869

Would appreciate any feedback on it.

Thank you!
Junho

Patch Set 9:

(2 comments)

Seems interesting. No strong opinions; the threads and explicit sleep stuff seem unfortunate but I haven't thought about it all too deeply. I made a couple of superficial comments.
Looks like you'll still need to manually scrub the whitespaces.

Please fill this section out.

I think it'd be good to give examples of how you used it in real life(how you get the PID of hwmon for instance).

It'd also be beneficial for future developers (who may not be as familiar with PTRACE as you) for you to unravel what's happening in "init" as there's a lot in there, especially with what uregs refer to what. Bonus points for pointing to some documentation you followed as well.

Same with above:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#variables

"Variables should all be lowerCamelCase, including class members, with no underscores."

I think it'd be good to back this up with a reference.

Something like: 
https://www-numi.fnal.gov/offline_software/srt_public_context/WebDocs/Errors/unix_system_errors.html
I think it'd be good to note that the error codes should be in positive (as sometimes, we may think of error codes as being negative).
Should there also be a limit?
What does wstatus stand for? wait status? If it is, I think it'd be better if it was written as waitStatus
I think a brief comment explaining what this code block is doing will help with future debugging.

Same with above:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#variables

"Variables should all be lowerCamelCase, including class members, with no underscores."

I usually prefer to have logs or comments at early exits like this, but since we don't want to fill the logs, I think it'd be good to have a short comment explaining what it means for "_is_active" to not be true (since the reader maybe too lazy to scroll up to the header for what "_is_active" is for).
Same here (although I guess it's somewhat obvious).
If you're going to break with the "if", I think it's cleaner to read if you just take out the else here (saves on indentation).

Same with above:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#variables

"Variables should all be lowerCamelCase, including class members, with no underscores."
Same as above, a brief comment on what's going on here (and why we're continuing early after doing PTRACE_SYSCALL)

Same with above:

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#variables

"Variables should all be lowerCamelCase, including class members, with no underscores."
What are we trying to do here?
Could this be factored out to a separate method?
I think I may need some explanation of what math is going on here.
Let's use a constant instead of a magic number here. You'll want to update the comment description of `init` as well as it references 5 seconds.
maybe uint32_t or uint64_t since we can't have this be negative?

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#variables

"Variables should all be lowerCamelCase, including class members, with no underscores."
Maybe clarify that you're referring to sys open

Same with above (ditto to everything below as well):

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#variables

"Variables should all be lowerCamelCase, including class members, with no underscores."
I believe int is sufficient for file descriptor
I used a long here because when the file descriptor is extracted out of memory, it must be extracted out as a long - I wanted to avoid any conversion issues that may occur.
You don't really need a README for the test directory.
nit: Could you try running clang-format again? Technically this is over the 80 char limit, but I'm not sure if there's exceptions for things like this (links, etc. that need to be continuous).
Put an explicit inline because it was inlined previously but I removed it since the compiler is probably doing it anyways
I think we should name this README.md so that it is parsed as a markdown document - would recommend following the markdown format as well. https://www.markdownguide.org/basic-syntax/
It would be nice if you could include what command you ran to figure out this systemctl instance name.

(via ctrl+z and bg command)

I believe is how you do it?
I don't think we should be maintaining a README and a README.md. Or is Gerrit doing something silly with symlinks?

nit: I think it'd be good to give an example grep filter after this line.
Something like: 

For example: `systemctl | grep xyz.openbmc_project.Hwmon@`
For markdown, it's good to wrap the individual lines with `` to indicate that it's code.
Why is this necessary when you're already including sys/syscall.h?
